title: Mechanisms leading to improved mechanical performance in nanoscale alumina filled epoxy
abstract: There have been several reports of improved ductility and toughness in brittle thermoset polymers due to the addition of equiaxed nanoparticles [Ash BJ, Siegel RW, Schadler LS. Mechanical behavior of alumina/poly(methyl methacrylate) nanocomposites. Macromolecules 2004;37:1358–69; Kinloch AJ, Lee JH, Taylor AC, Sprenger S, Eger C, Egan D. Toughening structural adhesives via nano-and micro-phase inclusions. J Adhes 2003;79:867–73; Kinloch AJ, Mohammed RD, Taylor AC, Eger C, Sprenger S, Egan D. The effect of silica nanoparticles and rubber particles on the toughness of multiphase thermosetting epoxy polymers. J Mater Sci 2005;40:5083–6; Johnsen BB, Kinloch AJ, Mohammed RD, Taylor AC, Sprenger S. Toughening mechanisms of nanoparticle-modified epoxy polymers. Polymer 2007;48:530–41]. The mechanisms leading to this improvement, however, are incompletely understood. In this paper, a model system of nanoscale alumina filled bisphenol A based epoxy with two interface conditions was used to highlight the mechanisms leading to significant improvements in both ductility (max 39%) and modulus (max 18%). Tensile test showed that crack deflection, debonding and plastic deformation of the debonded matrix (plastic void growth) operated for the untreated particles with a relatively weak interface, but that a stronger interface led to enhanced crack deflection and microcracking, and, as a result, a further improvement in properties.
body: Introduction

Bisphenol A based epoxides are used in applications ranging from electric insulators to adhesives to composite resins [bib5 bib6 bib7]. Like other thermosetting materials, however, they are brittle. Therefore, micron-sized fillers have been added to epoxy resin to form composites with a better combination of mechanical, thermal and electrical properties [bib8]. Toughening epoxy by soft particles, such as rubber, is widely used [bib9 bib10 bib11], but reduces the stiffness of the epoxy. Rigid particles have also been used to improve the stiffness of epoxy. The limitation of such fillers is that they cause a decrease in ductility and opacity [bib12]. Recently, nanoscale fillers have been used to try to overcome these limitations [bib13]. The small particle size leads to smaller defects and increases particle/matrix interfacial area which provides and opportunity to tailor composite properties, even at a rather low filler loading [bib14 bib15 bib16]. Ash et al. [bib1] report that at an optimum weight fraction, the nanosized alumina filled PMMA composites display a room-temperature brittle-to-ductile transition in uniaxial tension with an increase in the strain-to-failure that averages 40% strain. Kinloch et al. [bib2 bib3 bib4] observed a doubling of the fracture toughness in nanosilica filled epoxy nanocomposites.

There are a set of models that address mechanisms leading to enhanced ductility when either rubber particles or rigid particles are used as fillers, including crack deflection theory by Faber and Evans [bib17 bib18], and by Spanoudakis and Young [bib19 bib20]; crack pinning theory by Lange [bib21], Evans [bib22], and Green et al. [bib23]; debonding theory by Evans et al. [bib24]; plastic void growth theory by Huang and Kinloch [bib11 bib4]; and particle pull-out and microcracking. This paper attempts to clarify the mechanisms operating in nanofilled epoxy; and in the discussion section, a quantitative comparison of our results with the theories suggests that the operative mechanisms are interface dependent.
Crack deflection

Crack deflection causes an increase in the total fracture surface area and therefore absorbs more energy compared to unfilled polymer materials. This increase in area can be evaluated by measuring the fracture surface roughness [bib27]. Crack deflection also causes the crack to grow locally under mixed-mode I/II or I/III conditions, the impact of which of toughness can be evaluated by Faber and Evans’s crack deflection theory [bib17 bib18]. A lower bound toughness increment is believed to result from the increase in surface area according to [bib17] (1) G Ic G Ic,m = 1 2 1 + ( Δ / 2 ) 2 + r 2 Δ / 2 , where G Ic is the fracture energy of the nanocomposites; G Ic,m is that of the epoxy matrix; r is the radius of the particle; Δ is the center-to-center interparticle distance, which only depends on r and the volume fraction of filler, V f [bib17].

The toughening increment due to deflection by tilt and twist is described by [bib17] (2) G Ic,m G Ic = 1 ϕ max ∫ 0 ϕ max sin ϕ sin ϕ + cot ϕ [ ( k 1 ti ) 2 + ( k 2 ti ) 2 ] d ϕ + 1 ϕ max ∫ 0 ϕ max cot ϕ cos ϕ sin 2 ϕ + cot ϕ 1 ϕ ∫ 0 ϕ k 1 tw d ϕ 2 + 1 ϕ ∫ 0 ϕ k 3 tw d ϕ 2 d ϕ , where k 1 ti and k 2 ti are the local stress intensity factors for the tilted crack, and k 1 tw and k 3 tw are those for the twisted crack, respectively, ϕ is the deflection angle, ϕ max is the maximum deflection angle and only depends on Δ and r(ϕ max =sin−1(2r/Δ) [bib17].
Crack pinning

Crack pinning theory as an energy absorbing mechanism was first proposed by Lange [bib21]. He suggested that rigid particles can act as effective pinning points during fracture; a fracture step then forms which occurs as ‘tail’ [bib21 bib12].

Based on Lange’s crack pinning theory, Evans [bib22], followed by Green [bib23], determined the increase in toughness of a brittle particle reinforced composite by calculating the stresses needed to propagate these secondary cracks, which were summarized by Spanoudakis [bib19]. The toughening increment G Ic / G Ic,m is related to (3) σ c σ m = E c G Ic E m G Ic,m , where σ c / σ m is the ratio of the stress required to propagate a crack in the composite to the stress required for a crack in pure matrix, which is given in terms of the ratio of the particle diameter to the interparticle separation, d / τ ( d / τ = 1 [ π / 6 V f ) 1 / 3 - 1 ] ) , E c and E m are Young’s modulus of composite and matrix, respectively.
Debonding and plastic void growth

Debonding of rigid particles absorbs energy and depends on the adhesion between the particles and epoxy matrix [bib24]. The debonding of the particles enables local plastic void growth to occur. In a tensile test, the area under stress–strain curve, W, is also known as the stored strain–energy density [bib25 bib26]. Huang and Kinloch [bib11] developed a model using strain–energy density to confirm whether plastic void growth could be responsible for toughening. This model assumes linear elastic behavior, and that the energy dissipation is localized to a small plastic zone at the crack tip. The contribution to the increase in strain–energy density, characterized by the area under stress–strain curve, from the plastic void growth mechanism is given by [bib11] (4) Δ W v = 0.5 σ yt ( V v - V f ) , where V v is the volume fraction of voids, V f is the volume fraction of particles, σ yt is the tensile yield stress (the stress at the maximum on stress–strain curve [bib5]) of the unmodified epoxy polymer.
Particle pull-out and microcracking

Particle pull-out is due to the debonding of the nanoparticles and therefore will not be considered as an independent mechanism. Microcracks can be initiated due to the interaction of the crack front and the particles [bib28]. The main crack then deflects toward microcracks around the particle. Linkage of the main crack with the microcracks increases the total crack length and therefore, the energy absorbed.
Experimental
Materials

Huntsman Araldite® epoxy was chosen as the thermosetting matrix polymer, including (i) Araldite F – bisphenol A liquid epoxy resin; (ii) Aradur HY905 – modified dicarboxylic anhydride hardener; (iii) DY062 – amine catalyst. The mixing ratio of epoxy resin to hardener was 1:1 by weight. NanoTek® aluminum oxide (Al2O3) was purchased from Nanophase Technologies Corporation, with an average particle size of 45nm (determined from specific surface area). 3-Aminopropyltriethoxysilane (APTES) from Gelest Inc. was chosen to functionalize the alumina nanoparticles. The hypothesis was that the amino groups would react with the epoxy and the silane groups with the alumina surface, thus creating a relatively strong nanoparticle/epoxy interface.
Silane surface treatment

The alumina nanoparticle surface treatment procedure was: (i) addition of 1g of Al2O3 to 50ml of 95% ethanol; (ii) sonication of the mixture for 5min using a wand at 1min intervals; (iii) addition of 1.5g APTES ((C2H5O)3Si–CH2–CH2–CH2–NH2) and sonication of the mixture for another 10min; (iv) refluxing the mixture for 3days at 80°C in an oil bath; (v) centrifuging and washing the nanoparticles with ethanol and hexane to remove the byproducts and extra silane followed by drying of the particles in a vacuum oven at room temperature for 24h.
Nanocomposites preparation

NT-Al2O3 (non-treated alumina) and APTES–Al2O3 (3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane treated alumina) filled epoxy nanocomposites with 5, 10, 15 and 20phr (phr – per hundred gram resin) nanoparticle concentrations were prepared. Before using, the NT-Al2O3 nanoparticles were dried in vacuum at 190°C for 24h. Three steps were used to prepare the nanocomposites. First, the nanoparticles were dispersed in the liquid epoxy resin (Araldite F) to prepare a “masterbatch”. A well-dispersed masterbatch was achieved by shear mixing at 3450rpm for 20min using a Hauschild SpeedMixer® (DAC-150). Because the surface modified Al2O3 nanoparticles aggregate easily after the centrifuging and drying processes, for the APTES–Al2O3 nanocomposites, the dispersion was improved by adding 1/8” alumina balls during mixing. The balls were removed before curing. Second, the hardener (Aradur HY905) and catalyst (DY062) were added as per composition requirements into the masterbatch. Third, the mixture was mixed, degassed at room temperature, cured at 80°C for 6h, and post-cured at 135°C for 10h. Neat polymer samples were made to compare with the nanocomposites. Silicone rubber molds were used to prepare the test samples.
Characterization

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a TA® Instruments model Q50 TGA in N2 for both treated and untreated nanoparticles to determine the surface coverage of the silane coupling agent on the nanoparticles. A 10–50mg sample was heated from 25°C to 900°C with a constant heating rate of 10°C/min. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectra were obtained on a Nicolet 4700 FT-IR spectrometer in transmission mode. Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) model Q100 from TA® Instruments was used to check the glass transition temperature (T g) to ensure complete curing. The samples were heated from 25°C to 160°C with a constant heating rate of 10°C/min. Data obtained from the second heating run were used, and at least three samples were tested for each material.
Tensile tests

Tensile tests were performed on an Instron 4204 tensile test machine with a constant loading speed of 0.1mm/min according to ASTM D638. The stress–strain curves of the materials were obtained, and Young’s modulus, ultimate tensile strength, strain-to-break, and area under stress–strain curve were measured. At least eight samples were tested for each condition. The dog-bone tensile test samples with 3×3mm cross-section were molded from silicone rubber molds and polished on both sides before loading.
Fracture surface properties

Surface roughness of tensile fracture surfaces were measured at the University of Florida using a Dektak® 8 Advanced Development Profiler from Veeco Instruments Inc. 2D scans were performed by this stylus profilometer with a 12.5μm needle. At least 10 scan were performed for each material at different positions and the average roughness was calculated using Dektak® 8 software. A JEOL 6330F field emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) and a JEOL CM12 transmission electron microscope (TEM) were used to observe the dispersion of nanoparticles and morphology of fracture surfaces of the tensile test samples.
Results
Surface coverage of silane

The TGA thermograms for APTES (3-aminopropyltriethoxysilane, C9H23NO3Si) treated particles showed a significant mass loss, indicating the presence of coupling agent (not shown here). Approximately, 8.3μmol/m2 surface coverage of the APTES silane was present on the Al2O3 nanoparticles after the solution treatment. The calculation was based on the assumption that the APTES silane hydrolyzed completely and the difference in weight loss at 900°C between the APTES–Al2O3 and the NT-Al2O3 nanoparticles was due to the loss of hydrocarbon components of the silane. The hydroxyl group density on the surface of NT-Al2O3 nanoparticles was also approximated from the TGA thermograms, assuming that the weight loss above 400°C was due to condensation of surface hydroxyl groups [bib29]. The density of the surface hydroxyl group coverage was about 9.4μmol/m2 and in agreement with previously reported values [bib29]. By comparing the surface hydroxyl concentration (9.4μmol/m2) of the NT-Al2O3 nanoparticles with the silane coverage (8.3μmol/m2) of the APTES–Al2O3 nanoparticles, it is likely that a monolayer of silane formed on the particle surface. Effective silane coupling and complete hydrolysis of silane were also evident from the FTIR data, for the surface treated nanoparticles (not shown here).
Dispersion of nanocomposites

Good dispersion is critical for taking advantage of nanoscale particles and obtaining optimized properties. [fig1]
                         shows the dispersion in the NT-Al2O3 and APTES–Al2O3 nanocomposites. Many of the nanoparticles are individually dispersed. Only a few agglomerates (approximately 4–8) with a diameter of 2–6μm on the 3×3mm cross-section of each nanocomposite were observed (not shown here). A comparison of [fig1]b and d show that the nanoparticle/epoxy adhesion was stronger for the APTES–Al2O3 nanocomposites, which was due to the surface treatment of the Al2O3 nanoparticles by APTES silane.

Tensile properties

The tensile properties including Young’s modulus, ultimate tensile strength and strain-to-break of neat polymer, NT-Al2O3/epoxy and APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites are listed in [tbl1]. [fig2] shows the representative stress–strain curves for neat polymer, 10phr NT-Al2O3 and 10phr APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites obtained by tensile tests. It is clear that the strain-to-break for the 10phr APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite ([fig2]c) increased significantly compared to the neat polymer ([fig2]a). The strain-to-break of the 10phr NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite ([fig2]b) did not change compared to the neat polymer. t-Test (a statistical hypothesis test) results show that the mean strain-to-break of the 10phr APTES–Al2O3 nanocomposites is significantly higher than the neat polymer at a 95% confidence level (the increase is 39%); and for 15phr APTES–Al2O3 nanocomposites, it is significantly higher than the neat polymer at a 90% confidence level (the increase is 31%).

[fig3] shows Young’s modulus of the neat polymer, NT-Al2O3/epoxy and APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites as a function of nanoparticle concentration. The modulus increased with nanoparticle concentration. The increase in modulus is expected because the modulus of Al2O3, E =360GPa [bib33], is much greater than that of the epoxy matrix (3.2GPa). Although both the treated and the untreated nanoparticles lead to enhanced stiffness, the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites exhibited a lower modulus over the whole range of filler loading of interests compared to the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites ([tbl1]).

The Halpin–Tsai prediction [bib34 bib35] is shown in [fig3]d with the experimental data. The agreement between the prediction and the experimental data is reasonable. The measured moduli of the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites generally lie slightly below the predicted relationship. This is commonly observed because the model assumes that the particle/matrix interface is perfectly bonded. Although the interface adhesion condition is improved by surface modified Al2O3 nanoparticles with APTES silane, it was still not perfect ([fig1]c and d). However, the measured moduli of the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites are slightly above the predicted line. This result can be considered further using the Lewis–Nielsen model [bib36] and the work of McGee and McCullough [bib37].

The Lewis–Nielsen predictions for non-agglomerated spheres with two different interface conditions (with slippage and no slippage) bracket the experimental data of APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites ([fig3]a and b), which indicates that there is likely to be imperfect adhesion between the particles and matrix. This result corresponds to the predictions from Halpin–Tsai model. At the same time, the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite shows lower modulus than the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite over the whole range of filler loading. This phenomenon was also observed by Wu et al. [bib38] for the surface modified SiO2 filled polypropylene. It is well known that a stronger interface can lead to a higher modulus, as predicted by Lewis–Nielsen model. However, in this case, the soft layer of the APTES may be reducing the reinforcing effect of the nanoparticles. In addition, the moduli of NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites are even higher than the Lewis–Nielsen prediction for non-agglomerated spheres with a perfect interface ([fig3]b). Nielsen and Landel [bib8] noted that the agglomeration and structuring decreases the maximum packing value ϕ max, and therefore, increases the modulus of the composite. Therefore, the higher moduli may imply that more agglomerates are present in the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites.

The strain-to-break, or ductility of material, as a function of nanoparticle concentration for both of the NT-Al2O3 and APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites are listed in [tbl1]. Consider first the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites. For the 5, 15 and 20phr nanocomposites, the mean strain-to-break decreased compared to the neat polymer. However, the 10phr nanocomposite stands out. Usually, the incorporation of micron-sized particulate fillers results in a decrease in strain-to-break regardless of the interfacial adhesion [bib39]. All of the strain-to-break values for APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites are higher than both the neat polymer and the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites at the same particle loading, except for 20phr. The 11°C decrease in glass transition temperature for 20phr samples might explain this decreased ductility.
Fracture surface morphology

The fracture morphology of the tensile bars for neat polymer, 10phr NT-Al2O3 and 10phr APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites are shown in [fig4]
                        . The well-known ‘mirror’, ‘mist’ and ‘hackle’ zones [bib27] on the tensile fracture surfaces can be clearly seen for all three materials. Fracture nucleated at a minute flaw and propagated normal to the tensile axis. In the initial stages, the crack grew slowly, which produced a very smooth fracture surfaces: the ‘mirror’ zone [bib40] (denoted by ‘A’). The ‘mirror’ region is surrounded by a slightly rougher and less reflective region called the ‘mist’ zone (denoted by ‘B’). The very thin ‘mist’ zone merges into a very rough 3D surface called the ‘hackle’ zone (denoted by ‘C’), which occurs when the crack reaches its limiting speed and excess stored energy was dissipated in bifurcation [bib40].

The enlarged SEM images in the ‘mirror’ zones for the neat polymer, 10phr NT-Al2O3 and 10phr APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites are shown in [fig5] . Unlike the very smooth ‘mirror’ zone of neat polymer ([fig5]a), both the 10phr NT-Al2O3 and 10phr APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites have a slightly rougher ‘mirror’ zone ([fig5]b and e), which indicates increasing surface roughness due to crack deflection [bib27]. The high magnification SEM images show that the fracture surfaces of the 10phr NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite ([fig5]c) and the 10phr APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite ([fig5]f) are quite similar inside the ‘mirror’ zone. Particle pull-out (toughening mechanism A in [fig5]), debonding between nanoparticles and matrix and plastic void growth (indicated by the voids around the nanoparticles, toughening mechanism B in [fig5]) can be clearly seen in both materials. Particle pull-out, which leaves hemispherical holes on the fracture surface, is due to the debonding of the nanoparticles and therefore, will not be considered as an independent mechanism. As discussed previously ([fig1]d), stronger nanoparticle/epoxy adhesion is found in the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites before the tensile test; however, this stronger interface debonded here. In addition, voids formed around both NT-Al2O3 and APTES–Al2O3 nanoparticles. Johnsen et al. [bib4] reported that plastic void growth was the main toughening mechanism for nanosilica particles filled epoxy composites with weak interface between the nanoparticles and the matrix. In the present work, plastic void growth (toughening mechanism B) exists in both NT-Al2O3 and APTES–Al2O3 nanocomposites. By carefully examining the SEM images, it was found that voids deform more for the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites ([fig5]f and g) than that for the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites ([fig5]c and d). For the sake of simplicity, the voids are assumed to be spherical. The average void to particle size ratio d v/d f, measured from the SEM images was 1.1 for the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites and 1.3 for the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites.

[fig6]
                        a–e shows the enlarged SEM images in the ‘hackle’ zones for the neat polymer, 10phr NT-Al2O3 and 10phr APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites. Large hackle markings can be seen in the neat polymer ([fig6]a). However, the fracture morphologies of NT-Al2O3 and APTES–Al2O3 nanocomposites are quite different from the neat polymer. The much rougher fracture surfaces with 3D fine hackle markings appear in the nanocomposites ([fig6]b and d). The high magnification SEM images show that the fracture surfaces of the 10 phr NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite ([fig6]c) and the 10phr APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite ([fig6]e) are different inside the ‘hackle’ zone. In the poorly-bonded NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite, the particles can be seen clearly and the crack seems to have propagated around their equator. The fracture surface, therefore, consists of hemispherical holes and the top surface of debonded particles (morphology A and B in [fig6]c); however, in the well-bonded APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite, the particles are not as distinct and the epoxy resin matrix covers the particles (morphology C in [fig6]e), which indicates that the crack may propagate through the matrix above or below the poles of the particles. The interfacial debonding observed in the ‘mirror’ zone of APTES–Al2O3 nanocomposite was not seen in ‘hackle’ zone.

Transmission electron micrographs perpendicular to the tensile fracture surface (denoted by FS in the figures) in the ‘hackle’ zone of 10phr NT-Al2O3/epoxy and 10phr APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites are shown in [fig7]
                        . Microcracking and debonding away from the crack is not observed in the 10phr NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite ([fig7]a). However, small wave-like structures are observed near the fracture surface of the 10phr NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite, indicating microcracking ([fig7]b).
Discussion

It is clear from the results that the silane treated APTES–Al2O3 particle filled nanocomposites showed significant increases in strain-to-break (39% at 10phr filler loading) while exhibiting an increase in modulus and maintained strength in tensile tests. Many authors have also observed that addition of particles to a brittle material increase the toughness [bib3 bib4 bib41]. In this study, tensile toughness of the nanocomposite will be characterized by the area under stress–strain curve, W [bib42 bib43]; therefore, the fracture toughness increment G Ic/G Ic,m used in the theoretical models in the introduction will be replaced by W c /W m, where W c is the tensile toughness of the composite and W m is that of the epoxy matrix. The possible toughening contributions will be discussed in detail, and predicted by analytical models in the following section.
Crack deflection

As mentioned in the introduction, increasing fracture surface roughness can be used as evidence to prove crack deflection is occurring, which increases the crack length and therefore, the energy absorbed during deformation [bib27]. The roughness in the ‘mirror’ zone was too small, therefore, only the surface roughness in the ‘hackle’ zone as a function of nanoparticle concentration (phr) are presented in [fig8]
                        . The fracture surface roughness of NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites increases with the filler loading (maximum 1400nm), which indicates increasing crack deflection and crack length. All of the fracture surface roughness values of APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites are higher than both neat polymer and NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites at the same particle loading (except for 20phr), which indicates more crack deflection for the treated nanocomposites. Spanoudakis and Young’s argument [bib20] suggest that for poorly-bonded NT-Al2O3 particles, the maximum tensile stress is at the equators of the particles, which means the cracks propagating through the composite are attracted to the equator of the particles and then merge into the debonded particle/matrix interface ([fig6]f). The fracture surface, therefore, consists of hemispherical holes and the top surface of debonded particles (morphology A and B in [fig6]c), and the fracture surface roughness is low. For the well-bonded APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite, the maximum stress is in the matrix above and below the poles of the particle [bib20], which means the cracks are attracted to the matrix near the poles of the particles ([fig6]g), and therefore, the fracture surface roughness increases. The SEM morphology supports this (morphology C in [fig6]e), because in the APTES–Al2O3 nanoparticles there is a layer of epoxy resin covering the particles. It is clear that crack deflection occurred in both nanocomposites; however, the crack deflected more in the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites.

The measured tensile toughness (area under stress–strain curve) may also be compared to Faber and Evans’ crack deflection theory [bib17 bib18]. The experimental data of W c /W m and the theoretical predictions from Faber and Evans models are shown in [fig9] . Curve (a) represents the lower bound increment from surface area increase; (b) and (c) are the increment contributed from the crack tilt and twist, where (b) assumes a uniform spacing of particles – perfect dispersion, and (c) assumes a distributed spacing of particles. The agreement between experimental data and the predictions is reasonable only at low volume fraction (no significant T g change range) for the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites. The discrepancy between the experimental data and the predictions for the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites indicates that there is a competing mechanism, probably agglomeration, which decreases the tensile toughness.

In addition, the correlation between the fracture surface roughness and the area under stress–strain curve (tensile toughness) for both nanocomposites compared with the neat polymer are presented in [fig10]
                        . For APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites, except for 20phr samples, a linear correlation line can be drawn, indicating an increase in toughness due to crack deflection; however, there is no clear relationship between roughness and tensile toughness for the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites.
Crack pinning

A comparison of the predicted σ c/σ m ratio by Evan’s and Green’s theories and the experimental σ c/σ m ratio calculated from the ratio of tensile toughness, represented by the area under stress–strain curve W c/W m did not correlate. Johnsen et al. [bib4] argued that crack pinning occurred when the particles were larger than the crack-opening displacement, which is 1.7μm for neat epoxy matrix. Therefore, nanoparticles are unlikely to cause crack pinning.
Debonding and plastic void growth

As discussed in Section [sec1], an idealized debonding law was proposed by Evans et al. [bib24]. However, this theory is difficult to use for tensile test results, because the size of the plastic zone ahead of the crack tip can not be directly calculated. The fracture morphology might be the only evidence. Debonding between well-bonded APTES–Al2O3 nanoparticles from the epoxy matrix, which depends on the crack propagation speed [bib40], is observed in the ‘mirror’ zone on the fracture surface of the nanocomposite ([fig5]f and g); however, poorly-bonded NT-Al2O3 nanoparticles debonded everywhere through the whole sample (Figs. [fig5]c & d and [fig6]c). Therefore, the increments due to the interfacial debonding for the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy and NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite are very difficult to compare, which indicates that debonding is important but not the main mechanism that distinguishes the two nanocomposites with different interface conditions.

Johnsen et al. [bib4] proved in their work, using the Huang and Kinloch theory, that plastic void growth could be the main toughening mechanism in SiO2 nanoparticle filled epoxy nanocomposites. In the present work, plastic void growth was observed in the ‘mirror’ zone of both the NT-Al2O3/epoxy and the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites ([fig5]c, d, f and g) and in the ‘hackle’ zone of the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposite ([fig6]c), indicating it could be another toughening mechanism. The Huang and Kinloch model [bib11] can be used to confirm whether the plastic void growth could be responsible for the toughening effect. The average void to particle size ratio d v/d f, measured from the SEM images ([fig5]c and f), was 1.1 for the NT-Al2O3/epoxy and 1.3 for the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy. Therefore, d v/V f and V v/V f =1.33 were used in the prediction for the NT-Al2O3/epoxy and the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy, respectively. In addition, plastic void growth was only observed in the ‘mirror’ zone of the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites ([fig5]f and g), which was about 20% of the whole fracture surface area ([fig4]c). For the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites, plastic void growth can be seen across the whole fracture surfaces (Figs. [fig5]c & d and [fig7]c); therefore, it was assumed that all of the particles initiate the growth of voids. [fig11] shows the experimental data (points) and theoretical predictions (line (a) and (b)) from Huang and Kinloch’s theory of strain–energy density, characterized by the area under stress–strain curve, W [bib25 bib26], as a function of nanoparticle volume fraction for NT-Al2O3 and APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites. The agreements between the experimental data and the theoretical prediction fit well for the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites, but are low for the APTES–-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites, indicating that plastic void growth may be the main mechanism for the NT-Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites. However, the higher values of the data points for the APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites indicate the existence of other mechanisms.
Particle pull-out and microcracking

Other minor toughening mechanisms such as particle pull-out and microcracking can be observed by SEM or TEM. The particle pull-out mechanism exists in both NT-Al2O3 and APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites ([fig5]d and g). However, microcracks are only seen in APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites close to the fracture surface ([fig7]b).
Conclusions

APTES silane graft Al2O3 nanoparticles were prepared by solution treatment. The tensile properties of well-dispersed NT-Al2O3 and APTES–Al2O3/epoxy nanocomposites with different nanoparticle loadings were measured. There was no change in the glass transition temperature for most of the nanocomposites. APTES–Al2O3 nanoparticle filled epoxy showed significant increases in strain-to-break (39% at 10phr particle loading) while exhibiting an increase in modulus and maintained strength. The toughening mechanisms including crack deflection, debonding and plastic deformation of the debonded matrix (plastic void growth) work for both untreated and treated nanocomposites. However, further crack deflection and microcracking are the mechanisms distinctively for the treated nanocomposites.
